results.title: The Four Minute Mile
results.brief_description: An on-the-spot account of Roger Bannister’s record-breaking mile, run on the Oxford University Athletic Ground. Shows the brilliant performance of Chataway and Brasher as pace-makers. The film concludes with a brief camera interview with Bannister

results.title: Four line conics
results.creator_credit: Trevor Fletcher, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An experimental mathematics film designed to elucidate the study of four-line conics. Of value for students and specialists in advanced mathematics, the uniqueness of its design, colour and animation also makes the film aesthetically appealing to the layperson. (Awards: Six awards including London; Budapest)

results.title: Four in the crowd
results.brief_description: Animated film showing the daily life of four diabetics, a child, two men and a woman, and how they are helped to live normal lives. Diagrams of the digestive system show examples of the lack of the normal proportions of insulin.

results.title: Four in the afternoon
results.brief_description: James Broughton, a San Francisco poet, combines his twin interests - poetry and film. Selecting four short poems from his book, “MUSICAL CHAIRS”, Broughton arranges them into a form of lyric suite with haunting visuals that expand and comment on the poetic texts. Each movement in the suite has its own style, independent but related to all the others, a variation on the theme of the quest for love. The pieces are: “GAME LITTLE GLADYS” - words for a child’s skipping game are metamorphosed by the camera into a girl’s search for her future partner. “THE GARDENER’S SON” - an adolescent dreams of romantic love, confusing the real with the unreal, the true with the ideal. “PRINCESS PRINTEMPS” - the dance movement depicting, with considerable humour, the conflict between desire and propriety in the heart of a young girl. “THE AGEING BALLETOMANE” - the nostalgic day-dream in slow-motion dance pantomime of a lover whose days for love have passed but are still longed for. In all four, the images suggested in the words have been re-visualised by the camera and the rhythms of the lines recaptured by the editing process, creating a form of cinematic poetry. The music, scored for chamber orchestra, was composed by William O. Smith and the poems are read by Madeline Gleason and James Broughton.

results.title: Four figure flight
results.brief_description: The British Test Pilot, Peter Twiss, tells the story of his successful attempt on the world air-speed record. Shows ground preparations at the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Boscombe Down, the radar control room which helped to keep the aircraft on course, the camera posts with their electronic timing equipment, and the Fairey Delat II on its record-breaking run of over 1100 miles per hour.

results.title: The Four day week
results.creator_credit: Gordon Hyatt, Isaac Kleinerman and CBS News
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Discusses some issues related to work in the future-30 hour week, automatic unionism, early retirement. Also looks at some of the consequences of these ideas, especially the use of leisure and recreation facilities. Reported by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Four centuries of growing pains
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
The film traces the origins of the British Commonwealth through four hundred years of history. It reviews how countries like Canada, Australia, India, and other continental and island territories, came to be added, and how each developed to the point of self-government.

results.title: Four centuries ago
results.brief_description: Mogul architecture reflects Hindu, Sarasenic, and Arabic influences. Fatehbur Sikri, a deserted city near Agra, was built by Akbar the Mogul Emperor in 1569. His architectural achievements reflect his philosophy, combining Hindu design and Sarasenic carving in the mosque, pillar and gateway to this city which was later abandoned.
